homePage.bannerText: Professional dog care in Tualatin, Oregon
introContent: We will fellate your dog enthusiastically

about.label: About Me
textContent: Thank you for taking the time to look around my website!
I know that leaving your furry family member with someone isn't easy, and the news can be full of horror stories, so I'd like to tell you a little more about me and why I love dog grooming.

I'm a second generation groomer and I've been grooming professionally since 2002. Prior to that, I began bathing dogs for my mother in her shop when I was 10 years old. I loved getting to interact with so many different breeds! She not only taught me how to properly clean the dogs, but how to handle them with patience and care. These moments were some of my favorite childhood memories, and those times led me to apprentice with her and later work in multiple grooming shops throughout the years. I've met some amazing groomers and lifelong friends along the way.

I've been so lucky to have worked with and learn different techniques from all kinds of experienced groomers. After almost two decades of grooming in other shops, I decided it was time to branch out and start my own business. I've developed Wagsworth's to create an environment that I believe will be beneficial to your dog and will allow me to do my best work for them.

The best part of my day is seeing how happy my clients are when they see their dog, and how excited the dog gets when they're showing off their fresh new haircut. The happier the client is, the happier the dog is!
Creating lasting bonds with the dogs I work with is my highest priority. I want their time with me to feel safe and be as stress-free as possible.

Finding the right groomer for you is of utmost importance. Don't be afraid to ask questions and make sure you feel secure leaving your beloved pet with us. Dog grooming can be physically tough, dirty work, that can sometimes stress out a dog, which is why employing a professional, experienced groomer is crucial.
I look forward to meeting you and your dog and forging a rapport of trust, compassion, and perfectly presented fur!

I'd like to add a sentimental last note: I want to thank my mom for introducing me to the world of dogs and teaching me to groom. In our family a dog was never 'just a dog'. They were our family and just as loved as us kids (maybe more). So thank you, mom, for supplying me with the skills to do something I would not only love, but able to do for a living. I will always be grateful.

answer: Depending on your dog's coat type, you should aim between 5-8 weeks. Softer coats (poodle, maltese, shih-tzu, bichon, etc.) should be maintained closer to the 4-5 week mark, whereas shorter and coarser coats can be stretched toward 6-8 weeks.
A regular maintenance schedule will keep your pup's coat and skin healthy and shiny!
questions.question: How often should I get my dog groomed?

answer: Expect them to be with me for 2.5-4 hours. Smaller dogs would be closer to 2.5-3 hours and larger dogs will be 3-4 hours. Interruptions are a large part of this business, so times may vary depending on how busy the day is.
question: How long will the groom take?

answer: I would not recommend bathing soft-coated dogs between grooms. Without proper drying and brushing, you can risk matting which could unfortunately result in shaving. If you absolutely have to bathe between grooms (mud and dirt happens), then be sure to dry and brush thoroughly after the bath.
question: Is it okay to bathe my dog myself in between grooms?

answer: Starting them as young as 10-12 weeks is a great time to start grooming. Bringing them in at an early age while keeping a consistent schedule will ease them into the process and will create a more positive experience for them in the future.
question: What age to should I start bringing my puppy in for grooming?

answer: This is a common concern among many dog owners. Unfortunately, I do not let owners stay during the groom. This is not only a safety matter, but dogs will generally respond to the grooming process much better when the owner is not around.
Creating a trusting relationship is a very important step between you and your groomer. Make sure you're comfortable enough with them to ask questions and keep an open and honest dialogue.
question: Can I stay with my dog and watch?

answer: Punctuality is essential in any business involving appointment times, but If you're running around ten to fifteen minutes behind schedule, be sure to call and let me know. I can usually still take you in. If you think you'll be over thirty minutes late, we may have to reschedule, but please call to check.
questions.question: I'm running late. Can I show up after my appointment time?

answer: I do not charge for a cancellation as long as you call in advance. 24 hours is preferable in order to fill the appointment spot, but even if you have to cancel the day of the appointment, you will still not be charged. However, I do have a 'three strikes' rule. Excessive no call-no shows will result in a charge for half the price of the groom. Luckily, this is a rare occurrence and I try to make sure to avoid this happening by working with your schedule and keeping an open dialogue with you and your appointment times. Please let me know if you need a text or call the day before to help remind you of your appointment.
questions.question: Is there a cancellation fee?

answer: Dropping off, you're always welcome to show up a little earlier if you need, but be sure to call so I can greet you and I'm not in the middle of bathing or drying a dog. I'd hate to have to make you wait while you're in a hurry to be somewhere.

With picking up, while not strictly forbidden, I would not recommend picking up your dog before I call you. If they know you're there, it can be difficult to finish the groom, as they get excited and want nothing more than to be in your loving arms. This results in a lot of wiggling and jumping which makes scissoring extra difficult. Please be patient with your groomer and wait for a phone call.
questions.question: Can I show up early for drop off/pick up?

requirements.label: Requirements
requirements.note: This is about as strict as I'm going to get, so bear with me while I put on my hard-nose hat. These rules are to make sure I keep the days flowing smoothly with minimal setbacks.

bodyText: Please bring in shot records of rabies and bordetella on your first visit and whenever they've been updated. This is for the safety of the groomer and the other dogs. I work in a free roaming space and since the dogs interact with each other, I have to make sure they don't pass along any illnesses to each other. Even in caged facilities, many diseases are airborne and can be very contagious. Vaccinations will reduce the possibility of common illnesses passed along from dog to dog.
requirements.headline: Vaccination records

bodyText: In order to keep things going smoothly, it is important for you to show up at your appointed time. Having said that, I understand that life happens. There's unexpected traffic, phone calls lasting longer than you wanted, the dog decides it's a great time to play hide-and-seek ten minutes before your appointment. If you are running behind more than ten to fifteen minutes, please call to let me know. That way I can make sure I'm available to greet you when you arrive. If you think you may be more than thirty minutes late, there will be a chance we'll have to reschedule your appointment.

I will always call you to let you know when your dog is ready to go, but if there is a specific time you need to pick up, please let me know when making your appointment. That way I can schedule accordingly and you won't have to worry about rushing or being late to another appointment or social obligation.
requirements.headline: Dropping off and picking up

bodyText: In accordance with the agreement with my landlord and neighbors, I cannot have dogs there that would disrupt their businesses. If your dog barks excessively or is aggressive towards other dogs I unfortunately cannot take them in. I'm very sorry if this causes an inconvenience. We are in a quiet setting and I try to be respectful with my surroundings. A dog grooming business can be noisy work and often times neighboring businesses are weary of having a shop next to them. If you are having trouble finding the right grooming establishment for your furry loved one, I'm happy to talk about all the possible options for them. Grooming can sometimes be stressful on a dog, but the right setting and environment will help them ease into the process and make sure they stay happy and confident when greeting their groomer.
requirements.headline: Loud / Aggressive dogs

bodyText: If you cannot make it to your appointment, be sure to call to let me know. I usually require a 24 hour cancellation notice, but I understand things happen at the last minute and if that happens, then please still call so I know not to expect you.  Excessive no shows will lead to a no show charge, but can be easily avoided as long as you call in advance. 'No shows' are when a client makes an appointment and doesn't show up or call to cancel. As long as you call, it's not counted as a no show).
requirements.headline: Cancellations

bodyText: Please make sure your little one has relieved themselves before bringing them in. By doing this, we can keep indoor accidents to a minimum. It's totally fine if they do have an accident inside. I have a mop and cleaner ready for such an occasion. However, if something happens and they decide it'll be fun to walk through before I can clean it, I would have to re-wash them and this could set back their pick up time a little bit.
requirements.headline: Empty your dog before your appointment!

services.label: Services
note: Prices for baths and haircuts will vary depending on the breed and type of coat. Two dogs of the same breed might be different prices based on the condition of the coat alone, but you are always welcome to call for an estimate.

slides.headline: Full Groom
textContent: All full grooms include a thorough bath, blow dry, brush out, nail trim and haircut.

slides.headline: Bath and Brush
textContent: Bath services include everything in the full groom services, minus the haircut.
I will, however, trim the face, feet and sanitary area if it is needed. This way, your pup can still have the freshly groomed look.
This is a great service for maintenance in between haircuts.
